chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: This Getting Started Guide provides an introduction of the Cloud Feeds product. It also teaches how to use the Cloud Feeds API and to perform simple API operations. In this document, you will learn the following:

listitem.para: Chapter 3 describes how to send requests to the Rackspace API using cURL.
Chapter 4 shows how to obtain an authentication token to be used with the Cloud Feeds API.
Chapter 5 provides information on how to access the Cloud Feeds service through the service endpoints.
Chapter 6 introduces general concepts about Cloud Feeds, including Atom events.
Chapter 7 provides a set of steps on how you can use the Cloud Feeds API to retrieve feeds.

chapter.para: Follow the steps described in this guide to use the Rackspace Cloud Feeds API and programmatically access feeds.
For details about using the Cloud Feeds API, refer to the Cloud Feeds Developer Guide at http://docs.rackspace.com/.
Visit our Product Feedback Forum and tell us what you think about Cloud Feeds.

section.para:
In order to run the examples in this guide, you must have the following prerequisites:

section.title: Pricing and Service Level
section.para: Cloud Feeds is part of the Rackspace Cloud and your use through the API will be billed as specified in the pricing schedule at http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/public/databases/pricing.
The service level agreements (SLAs) for Cloud Feeds and Cloud Servers are available at http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/legal/sla/#cloud_databases and http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/legal/sla.

chapter.title: Sending Requests to the API
chapter.para: You have several options for sending requests through an API:

listitem.para: Developers and testers might prefer to use cURL, the command-line tool from http://curl.haxx.se/.
With cURL, you can send HTTP requests and receive responses back from the command line.
If you like to use a more graphical interface, the REST client for Firefox, also works well for testing and trying out commands. See https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/restclient/.
You can also download and install RESTclient, a Java application used to test RESTful web services, from http://code.google.com/p/rest-client/.

section.title: Sending API Requests Using cURL
section.para: cURL is a command-line tool that is available oin most UNIX system-based environments and Apple Mac OS X systems, and can be downloaded for Microsoft Windows to interact with REST interfaces. For more information on cURL, visit http://curl.haxx.se/.

cURL allows you to transmit and receive HTTP requests and responses from the command-line or from within a shell script. This makes it possible to work with the ReST API directly without using one of the client APIs.
The following cURL command-line options are used in this guide to run the examples.

chapter.title: Generating an Authentication Token
chapter.para: Whether you use cURL or a REST client to interact with the Cloud Feeds API, you must generate an authentication token. You provide this token in the X-Auth-Token header in each Cloud Feeds API request.
Examples 4.1 and 4.2 demonstrate how to use cURL to obtain the authentication token and your account number. You must provide both when making subsequent Cloud Feeds API requests.

Remember to replace the placeholder names in the following authentication request examples with your information:
yourUserName — Your common Rackspace Cloud username, as supplied during registration.
yourApiKey — Your API access key. You can obtain the key from the Rackspace Cloud Control Panel) by accessing selecting Account Settings from the yourAccount menu in the top-right corner of the window.
You can use either of the following endpoints to access the Authentication Service, regardless of US or UK identities:
Your account might be based in either the US or the UK; this is not determined by your physical location but by the location of the Rackspace retail site which was used to create your account:

listitem.para: If your account was created via http://www.rackspacecloud.com, it is a US-based account.
If your account was created via http://www.rackspace.co.uk, it is a UK-based account.

chapter.para: Notice that you authenticate by using a special URL for the Cloud authentication service. For example, you may use https://identity.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2.0/tokens, as shown in the following Authenticate Request examples. Note that the v2.0 component in the URL indicates that you are using version 2.0 of the Cloud Authentication API.

note.para: For UK-based accounts, you may decide to use 'https://lon.identity.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2.0/tokens' instead.

example.title: cURL Authenticate Request: XML
example.screen: curl -i -d \ '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <auth> <apiKeyCredentials xmlns="http://docs.rackspace.com/identity/api/ext/RAX-KSKEY/v1.0" username="yourUserName" apiKey="yourApiKey"/> </auth>' \ -H 'Content-Type: application/xml' \ -H 'Accept: application/xml' \ 'https://identity.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2.0/tokens'

chapter.para: The authentication token id is returned along with an expires attribute that specifies when the token expires.

listitem.para: The values that you receive in your responses vary from the examples shown in this document because they are specific to your account.

The information shown in the authentication response examples above is for US-based accounts. If you authenticate against the UK-endpoint for authorization service, you see the service catalog information for UK-based accounts.

The expires attribute denotes the time after which the token will automatically expire. A token may be manually revoked before the time identified by the expires attribute; expires predicts a token's maximum possible lifespan but does not guarantee that it will reach that lifespan. Clients are encouraged to cache a token until it expires.
Applications should be designed to re-authenticate after receiving a 401 (Unauthorized) response from a service endpoint.

chapter.para: The actual account number is located after the final slash (/) in the publicURL field. In the following examples, the account number is 1100111. You must specify your account number on most of the Cloud Feeds API operations, wherever you see the placeholder tenant id specified in the examples in this guide.
After authentication, you can use cURL to perform &GET; and &POST; requests for the Cloud Feeds API.

chapter.title: Cloud Feeds Concepts
chapter.para: Cloud Feeds uses AtomPub to publish different types of feeds. Feeds are composed of a number of items called entries. Each entry has an extensible set of attached metadata.

The AtomPub together with the Atom Syndication Format (ASF) provides a format for implementing web feeds. Web feeds provide users with frequently updated content. AtomPub is based on HTTP transfer of Atom-formatted representations. The Atom format is documented in the Atom Syndication Format.

Cloud Feeds is an open-source AtomPub server for accessing, processing, and aggregating Atom entries. Cloud Feeds was designed to make it easy to build both generalized and specialized persistence mechanisms for Atom XML data, based on the Atom Syndication Format and the Atom Publishing Protocol.
Cloud Feeds works the following way:

listitem.para: Events are generated by a publisher and added to the database as entries. Events can be usage events, system events or billing events.
Entries exist in Cloud Feeds for three days. After that time period they are deleted.

chapter.para: To read the official documentation for the Atom Syndication Format, see RFC 4287. For more information about AtomPub, visit http://atompub.org/.

section.title: Container Elements
section.para: An Atom feed consists of a series of container elements, which contain metadata or actual content related to the feed.
The Atom Publishing Protocol supports the following container elements:

section.title: Atom Feed Element
section.para: An Atom Feed element is a representation of an Atom feed, including metadata about the feed, and some or all of the entries associated with it.

The Atom Feed element represents the top-level element of an Atom Feed Document. It functions as a container for metadata and data associated with the feed. Its element children consist of metadata elements that are followed by zero or more Atom Entry child elements.
Following is an example of an Atom Feed element.

section.title: Atom Content Element
section.para: The Atom Content element either contains or links to the content of an entry. The type attribute specifies the MIME media type. If no type attribute is present, the content is treated as text.
Following is an example of an Atom Content element.

section.title: Atom Entry Element
section.para: The Atom Entry element represents exactly one Atom entry, outside of the context of an Atom feed. It functions as a container for metadata and data associated with the entry. This element can appear as a child of the Atom Feed element, or it can appear as the top-level element of a stand-alone Atom Entry Document.
Following is an example of an Atom Entry element.

section.title: Cloud Feeds Product Events
section.para: Cloud Feed places product events inside the Atom Content element. For example, the event element contains the product events (in this case for Cloud Backup product).

example.title: Cloud Backup Event Information
example.programlisting: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?atom feed="backup/events"?> <!-- ignore <?atom..?>, used for testing --> <atom:entry xmlns="http://docs.rackspace.com/core/event" xmlns:cb-bin="http://docs.rackspace.com/usage/cloudbackup/bandwidthIn" xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <atom:content type="application/xml"> <event endTime="2012-06-15T10:19:52Z" startTime="2012-06-14T10:19:52Z" region="DFW" dataCenter="DFW1" type="USAGE" id="8d89673c-c989-11e1-895a-0b3d632a8a89" resourceId="3863d42a-ec9a-11e1-8e12-df8baa3ca440" tenantId="1234" version="1"> <cb-bin:product version="1" serviceCode="CloudBackup" serverID="944576fa-ec99-11e1-bb8e-ebb21b47fa86" bandwidthIn="192998" resourceType="AGENT"/> </event> </atom:content> </atom:entry>

note.para: Cloud Feeds evaluates all product events against their XML schemas.
